channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-9243] Add more useful statistics in the HFile tool
item.description:
The HFile tool has been very useful to us recently to get a better idea of the size of our rows. However, it happened frequently that we wished for more statistics to have a more complete picture of the distribution of the row sizes.

Scott Kuehn requested that feature often enough in private that I decided to give it a go.

Here's the patch that adds more nice little stats via yammer's histograms. It was easy enough since com.yammer.metrics is already in hbase's dependencies.

Example of the new output from org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFile -s -f ...:


Stats:

	Key length:

               min = 24.00

               max = 24.00

              mean = 24.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 24.00

              75% <= 24.00

              95% <= 24.00

              98% <= 24.00

              99% <= 24.00

            99.9% <= 24.00

	Row size (bytes):

               min = 33.00

               max = 33.00

              mean = 33.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 33.00

              75% <= 33.00

              95% <= 33.00

              98% <= 33.00

              99% <= 33.00

            99.9% <= 33.00

	Row size (columns):

               min = 1.00

               max = 1.00

              mean = 1.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 1.00

              75% <= 1.00

              95% <= 1.00

              98% <= 1.00

              99% <= 1.00

            99.9% <= 1.00

	Val length:

               min = 1.00

               max = 1.00

              mean = 1.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 1.00

              75% <= 1.00

              95% <= 1.00

              98% <= 1.00

              99% <= 1.00

            99.9% <= 1.00

Key of biggest row: \x00
item.summary: Add more useful statistics in the HFile tool

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The description of the JIRA had all the juicy details of what I was including in the patch so there's nothing more to say here except that the patch is there and available for review.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12598361/HBASE-9243.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

This message is automatically generated.

-    public String toString() {

-      return "count: " + count +

Getting the count of key, value etc will be useful? How we can get the same now after the change?

All the addition of new stats LGTM

Looks good to me too. Good job Alex. Always good to have more information than less.

2 comments.
1) First comments as Anoop for the count. Is there a way to keep this information? It's good when you want to have a count based split policy and want to validate the content.

2) 


      simpleReporter.shutdown();

      simpleReporter.run();

      metricsRegistry.shutdown();

Should you also call metricsRegistry.run();? I don't really know yammer, so I'm just asking. Not suggesting.

I overlooked the fact that the ConsoleReporter doesn't print the histogram count by default. I just added it.

I also realized something while doing that: the count of Key length actually represented the count of key/value pairs so it was misrepresenting the count of keys (even though the key length was still accurate). I changed this so that the count of "Key length" accurately represents the number of keys.

Updated example (actually, it's against an entirely different hfile but you get the idea):


Stats:   Key length:

               min = 29.00

               max = 29.00

              mean = 29.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 29.00

              75% <= 29.00

              95% <= 29.00

              98% <= 29.00

              99% <= 29.00

            99.9% <= 29.00

            count <= 15

   Row size (bytes):

               min = 6921.00

               max = 455286.00

              mean = 320933.67

            stddev = 160821.04

            median = 346302.00

              75% <= 455190.00

              95% <= 455286.00

              98% <= 455286.00

              99% <= 455286.00

            99.9% <= 455286.00

            count <= 15

   Row size (columns):

               min = 110.00

               max = 7595.00

              mean = 5352.73

            stddev = 2685.21

            median = 5775.00

              75% <= 7594.00

              95% <= 7595.00

              98% <= 7595.00

              99% <= 7595.00

            99.9% <= 7595.00

            count <= 15

   Val length:

               min = 19.00

               max = 55.00

              mean = 22.96

            stddev = 1.48

            median = 23.00

              75% <= 23.00

              95% <= 23.00

              98% <= 23.00

              99% <= 23.00

            99.9% <= 23.00

            count <= 80291

Key of biggest row: \x7F\x80\x00\x00[\x80\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x0A

And Jean-Marc, about the run/shutdown sequence, I think I've got it right. The Reporter needs to run (to do the actual output to the ByteArrayOutputStream) and shutdown is just tidying up before terminating. There's no MetricsRegistry.run.

Thanks for this patch Alex!

I'm +1.

Anoop Sam John, fine with it too?

The output is confusing. 

Key length:

  count <= 15

The count could be less than 15? This is the count of different key lengths? Or total number of rows?

Val length:

  count <= 80291

The count could be less than 80291? This is the count of the number of different value lengths? Or total number of values?

the count of Key length actually represented the count of key/value pairs so it was misrepresenting the count of keys

So here what you changed is, it will track the count of RKs now.
+ curRowKeyLength = kv.getKeyLength();
This is the key length not the RK. So the previous thing was correct of tracking the #keys.
Key is RK +CF + Q + TS + Type

Any way we have the row count also.

I used the conservative yammer metrics style but, in this case, the count should be accurate so I'm changing this to report count = <value>.

As for your question regarding the number of different value lengths vs number of values, technically speaking, it's the count of samples of value length. In practice, that should be the same as saying the number of values in that file.

Here's the updated output from that last version:


Stats:   Key length:

               min = 29.00

               max = 29.00

              mean = 29.00

            stddev = 0.00

            median = 29.00

              75% <= 29.00

              95% <= 29.00

              98% <= 29.00

              99% <= 29.00

            99.9% <= 29.00

             count = 15

   Row size (bytes):

               min = 6921.00

               max = 455286.00

              mean = 320933.67

            stddev = 160821.04

            median = 346302.00

              75% <= 455190.00

              95% <= 455286.00

              98% <= 455286.00

              99% <= 455286.00

            99.9% <= 455286.00

             count = 15

   Row size (columns):

               min = 110.00

               max = 7595.00

              mean = 5352.73

            stddev = 2685.21

            median = 5775.00

              75% <= 7594.00

              95% <= 7595.00

              98% <= 7595.00

              99% <= 7595.00

            99.9% <= 7595.00

             count = 15

   Val length:

               min = 19.00

               max = 55.00

              mean = 22.96

            stddev = 1.48

            median = 23.00

              75% <= 23.00

              95% <= 23.00

              98% <= 23.00

              99% <= 23.00

            99.9% <= 54.00

             count = 80291

This is the count of different key lengths? Or total number of rows?

I think total number of rows

This is the count of the number of different value lengths? Or total number of values

Second.

Correct Alexandre Normand ?

Anoop Sam John: Strictly speaking, it's technically more accurate to say that those are the number of key lengths/number of value lengths sampled. But since all distinct keys are sampled once and each key has a sampled length, it's also the number of rows.

As for the number of values, it's slightly more complicated because it's technically possible to have multiple occurrences of the same key/family/qualifier/timestamp in the same hfile (I have an example at hand). In such a case, the reported number would include all value occurrences and not just the one that would be visible when querying the table. So, generally, it would be the number of values with the caveat that it's the number of values in the file and not necessarily the number of values one would see when querying hbase.

Last version fixed Andrew Purtell's concerns. So I guess we are all fine to get that committed?
Andrew Purtell If you are good, one of us can commit (nice addition BTW).
Sure. Will port and commit to 0.94 too. Ping Lars Hofhansl
Patch applies directly to 0.94 HFilePrettyPrinter with minor fuzz.
Committed to trunk and 0.95 branch. Will wait a few hours if nack on 0.94 before committing there too.
Can someone please assign this JIRA to Alex?
Done. He has credit in the commits also.

Thanks guys for the quick turnaround. Jean-Marc Spaggiari, you're like a father to me, making sure I'll be taken good care of...well, except that you're nothing like my father (he wouldn't be looking at JIRA).
